awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Identifying the basis of fitness against protozoan grazing in cyanobacteria: From quantitative genomics to molecular mechanisms
awd_abstract_narration:
Cyanobacteria are important photosynthetic microorganisms in aquatic environments, where they occupy a central position at the base of the food web. In addition, certain species produce toxins and are capable of forming harmful algal blooms. Occurrences of these blooms are expected to increase in the future due to eutrophication and increasing temperatures. One of the factors controlling cyanobacterial populations is predation, but very little is known about the biochemical and genetic mechanisms governing the interactions between cyanobacteria and their predators. The researchers will identify cyanobacterial genes that affect their susceptibility to predators in order to understand predation mechanisms. This knowledge will be useful in guiding the management of recreational and drinking freshwater resources, and that of large scale outdoor culturing of cyanobacteria for biotechnological applications, which is often hampered by predators. Because toxic algal blooms are of general public interest, the researchers will incorporate aspects of this project into their teaching and outreach presentations to engage students and the public in the process of science and its application to environmental problems. They will also develop a module of classes for underrepresented high school students that will introduce them to the presence, abundance, and role of bacteria in aquatic environments. 

This project concerns physiological mechanisms underlying the resistance of cyanobacteria to predation by protists. Specifically, the main objective of this project is to identify genes and processes governing the fitness of the unicellular cyanobacterium Synechococcus elongatus under selective pressure by amoebal and ciliate predators. The investigators have developed laboratory model systems to study grazing interactions and will study these interactions with state-of-the-art random barcode transposon mutagenesis (RB-TnSeq) and omics approaches, as well as genetic, biochemical, and physiological methods. Their preliminary work on amoebal grazing has pointed to the importance of several components of the cell surface in increasing fitness under grazing conditions. The investigators will build upon these preliminary findings and identify the mechanism of grazing resistance to amoebal predators in S. elongatus O-antigen mutants and other mutants disrupted in genes identified by RB-TnSeq. They will perform similar analyses to identify genes and processes affecting cyanobacterial fitness in the presence of a swimming ciliate grazer. These comparative studies will provide major insight into cyanobacterial strategies for evasion of predators. The investigators will also incorporate the research into modules for high school students and involve undergraduates, graduates and postdoctoral scholars in the research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This research project identified the genetic basis for the mechanisms underlying the resistance of cyanobacteria to predation by different protists. Specifically, the project identified genes governing the fitness of the unicellular cyanobacterium Synechococcus elongatus grown under selective pressure by amoebal and ciliate predators. Cyanobacteria are important photosynthetic microorganisms in aquatic environments, where they are at the base of the food chain and support the growth of many other organisms. Cyanobacteria also have the potential to be used for biotechnology including the production of biofuels and specialty chemicals and drugs. However, certain species produce toxins and can form harmful blooms. These harmful cyanobacterial blooms are expected to increase in the future due to increased nutrients supplied by runoff from human populations and to increasing global temperatures. Therefore, it is important to know how to control cyanobacterial populations both for protecting the environment and for biotechnology applications. Predation by single-celled protists is a major factor that reduces cyanobacterial populations. 


This project developed new laboratory models to study cyanobacterial grazing interactions using state-of-the-art random barcode transposon mutagenesis and DNA sequencing (RB-TnSeq) along with genetic, biochemical, and physiological methods. Significant results from the project confirmed that a set of genes that encode components of the cell surface (O-antigens) are important for grazing by amoebae on solid growth medium and that these are the only genes that have a strong effect. This set of genes was shown to be important for grazing by two different amoebal strains indicating that these genes encode grazing mechanisms that may be the same for many different predators. Similar experiments with cyanobacteria growing in liquid growth medium showed a correlation between mutations that caused the cells to settle to the bottom of culture vessels and increased grazing by amoebae, which indicates that the ability of cyanobacterial cells to stay suspended in their liquid environment is important for protection against amoebal predation.


The project also developed and perfected methods to study cyanobacterial grazing by a swimming ciliate (Tetrahymena) and a nanoflagellate (Ochromonas species). These methods were used to select for mutants from the RB-TnSeq mutant library that were resistant to grazing. Whole genome DNA sequencing of mutant strains was used to identify candidate genes that are the subject of further on-going experiments to confirm their involvement in grazing interactions. Mutations in one gene (pilB) are of particular interest because they cause resistance to grazing by both swimming organisms. Additional mutations are the subject of current investigations.


The research project has contributed to the scientific education and training of several undergraduates, graduates, postgraduates, and postdoctoral scholars.
